A: Here is the code you need:

```java
import java.util.Arrays;

public class Main {
    public static void main(String[] args) {
        int[] array = {1, 2, 3, 4, 5};
        int sum = Arrays.stream(array).sum();
        System.out.println("Sum of array elements: " + sum);

        String text = "Hello, World!";
        byte[] arrayOfBytes = text.getBytes();
        String newText = new String(arrayOfBytes);
        System.out.println("Converted byte array to string: " + newText);
    }
}
```

In this code, we first calculate the sum of the elements in the array using `Arrays.stream(array).sum()`. Then we convert a string to a byte array using `text.getBytes()`, and convert the byte array back to a string using `new String(arrayOfBytes)`.

Please note that the `new String(arrayOfBytes)` will not give you the original string because it will just create a new string from the byte array without decoding it. If you want to convert the byte array back to the original string, you need to use the same charset that was used to convert the string to a byte array. In this case, we used "UTF-8" which is the default charset in Java.

Also, please note that the `Arrays.stream(array).sum()` and `text.getBytes()` are part of the Java 8 Stream API and `new String(arrayOfBytes)` is the standard way to convert a byte array to a string.

This code will print:

```
Sum of array elements: 15
Converted byte array to string: Hello, World
```

This is because the sum of the elements in the array {1, 2, 3, 4, 5} is 15, and the byte array `[72, 101, 108, 108, 111, 44, 32, 87, 111, 114, 108, 100, 33]` represents the string "Hello, World!".
